textBoxes.message:
Welcome to the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign! You are an excited second semester freshman, ready to take on whatever college throws at you. What is your name? 
Enter name:

Hello, Miguel! Unfortunately, you returned to the wrong school at the wrong time. A serial killer is on the loose,
killing countless students across campus. Your mission: find out who the serial killer is before s/he kills you.
HOWEVER, be mindful of who you suspect. You might end up killing an innocent person, or even worse, a dear friend.
You don't get to choose your name. Your name is Miguel Fernandez
Okay...I guess my name is Miguel
No! I don't want to be Miguel. I want to change my name!

YOU DARE DEFY THE RULES OF THE GAME? This is what happens when you break the rules: YOU DIE.
You haven't even started the game yet, but a piercing sensation stabs through your back and rips through your chest.
You look down to see the end of a knife peeking out of your t-shirt, now stained by a growing pool of blood. You better clean up 
Oh, you can't.               
You're dead.
It is your first day of school. You wake up at Bromley, and you get ready to head to class. Hmm hot chocolate sounds pretty good right now
Grab some hot chocolate from the dispenser

Mmm nothing beats homemade hot chocolate!
Oops! It's 8:50am and you're running late for your first class: ECE 120. What do you do?
Skip ECE! Head to CS early instead

You made it! You're late, but you made it! You sit down in your seat and -- 

Screams pierce through your ear drums as an object - a knife? - slits your throat. You're still trying to register what happened, 
until the unmistakeable stinging pain burns at your neck, right where it was sliced. You reach for your throat, warm blood oozing from the fresh wound onto your fingers.

The pain drowns out the screams, no matter how near or loud they were. Your vision blurs, right before you fade away into nothingness.          
YOU DIED

You head straight to lincoln hall and spot Linh sitting in the back of the auditorium. You take your seat next to her.
"Do you want some hot chocolate?" you ask her.
Eyes widening, she nods eagerly.
You reach for your thermos, only to find out it's not in your backpack's side pocket."what?" you say. You swing your backpack forward and check the other side pocket."But i swear I brought it..."
Linh frowned, more so at the fact that she wouldn't have hot chocolate this morning. You got her hopes up. "Maybe it dropped?" She said.
You pout. "Maybe..." But if it dropped, you'd probably hear the thump of your thermos dropping. "What if... someone stole it?"
"Then you kill them" she calmly replies.
You forgot how violent linh's suggestions could be.
You two sit through lecture, and before you know it, class is over. Where do you go after class?

As you and Linh leave Lincoln Hall, you spot Sue Wee walking in your direction. "Sue!" you call.
She smiles and waves at the both of you.
"She probably has CS 173 right now," you say after she walks past.
"Yeah" Linh agrees.

Before you could even process the foot suddenly intercepting your immediate path, you miss a step and trip. Your arms flail in front of you, trying to save your fall, but a sharp object—a knife?—forcefully inserts itself into your back, pushing you to the pavement. Your forehead bangs to the ground. Shrieks echo across the quad, but you swear you hear a familiar voice muttering about low-quality hot chocolate. You don’t have time to decide whether or not you’re hearing things.

You spot Linh sitting in the back of the auditorium, and you take your seat next to her.
"Do you want some hot chocolate?" you ask her.
Eyes widening, she nods eagerly.
You reach for your thermos, only to find out it's not in your backpack's side pocket.
"What?" you say. You swing your backpack forward and check the other side pocket."But i swear I brought it..."
Linh frowned, more so at the fact that she wouldn't have hot chocolate this morning. You got her hopes up. "Maybe it dropped?" She said.
You pout. "Maybe..." but if it dropped, you'd probably hear the thump of your thermos dropping. "What if... someone stole it?"
"Then you kill them," she calmly replies.
You forgot how violent Linh's suggestions could be.
You two sit through lecture, and before you know it, class is over. Where do you go after class?

You two pass through the Union’s entrance, and Linh suddenly stops her tracks.

“Do I wanna nap or do I want Orange on Green?” she ponders aloud.

As you and Linh leave Lincoln Hall, you spot Sue Wee walking in your direction. "Sue!" you call.
She smiles and waves at the both of you.
"She probably has CS 173 right now," you say after she walks past.
"Yeah" Linh agrees.

You two head to the theater room in the Union’s basement, Linh entering first.

“There’s no one here!” she says before your eyes could adjust to the darkness.

You both settle in the reclining chairs in the back corner as usual, and you pull your jacket over you as a blanket. You turn to Linh, ready to tell her about your progress on the CS project, but she’s already knocked out. Somehow, seeing her passed out made you realize that you were also sleepy. Maybe the darkness was luring you to sleep. You feel your eyes droop.

You don’t wake up after that.

“Oh my God,” Linh says while chewing on her red bean bun. You notice her eyes are fervently darting back and forth, glued to her phone. She was reading something.

“What?” you ask.

Linh swallows her food. “They sent an Illini Alert. There was a murder in the ECE building.” She slides her phone to you.

“Holy shit.” You stare at her phone as you think about what could’ve happened had you not skipped class that morning. You shiver at the thought, the hairs on the back of your neck standing.

“Oh, it’s Ricky!” Linh says, looking behind you.

You turn around and Ricky was indeed in line for some pasta. It was your first time seeing him during class time this semester, just as it was your first time seeing others at the dining hall around this hour: KC, Linh’s neighbor, and Sue’s roommate. Orange on Green seemed to bring everyone together.

Ricky had turned his head in your directions when Linh said his name. “Oh!” he says, finally spotting the two of you. He waves and you wave back. 

“What’re your next classes?” he asks as he sits besides Linh.

“I have chem at 12,” Linh replies.

“Ew,” Ricky says.
"I have calc with Linh at One"

“Ew,” Ricky says even louder, gagging in disgust.

You and Linh smile in amusement. She asks Ricky if he’s heard about the murder.

“Wait, does this mean classes are canceled?” he asks.

“Wait, you’re right,” you say. If weather could cancel classes, surely a murder would.

“Lemme check,” Linh says, taking her phone back. After a few moments of tapping and scrolling, her eyebrows furrow in concern. “It doesn’t say anything—just a headline and a link to an article just saying they’ll investigate. There’s no email either.”

“What? You mean to tell me that we still got classes while a murderer is running amok?” Ricky asks.

“Yes,” Linh confirms. “Unless...this is fake.”

“But everyone got the alert,” Ricky says.

“Miguel, did you?” Linh asks.

You pull out your phone, and sure enough, there was a notification from an unsaved number with the same exact message as Linh’s. “Yeah.”

“That’s so weird,” Linh says. “Maybe Massmail just takes longer to send since they’re more detailed and properly formatted?”

“Girl, if there was a murder on my turf, I’d be telling everyone and their moms about it ASAP. Screw formatting. I’d type like Andrew if it means warning everyone faster,” Ricky says.

Linh frowned, knowing he made a good point.

“They’ll probably send an email soon,” you say, trying to convince yourself as well.

“Until then, I guess we still got class,” Linh sighs.

The three of you spend the rest of lunch in nervous conversation, glancing at each of your phones every now and then in anticipation for the Massmail.

No email came.

“I’m ‘a head out,” Linh says after checking the time.

“‘Ight, me too,” Ricky says as he begins cleaning up his lunch.

“Be safe,” you three tell each other.

You start clearing the table too, deciding you can continue working on CS at Grainger before calc.

Ricky grimaced. “Yeah, I did.”

An brief, unsettling silence followed.

“Wait, does this mean classes are canceled?” he suddenly asks.

“Wait, you’re right,” you say. If weather could cancel classes, surely a murder would.

“Lemme check,” Linh says, taking her phone back. After a few moments of tapping and scrolling, her eyebrows furrow in concern. “It doesn’t say anything—just a headline and a link to an article just saying they’ll investigate. There’s no email either.”

“What? You mean to tell me that we still got classes while a murderer is running amok?” Ricky asks.

“Yes,” Linh confirms. “Unless...this is fake.”

“But everyone got the alert,” Ricky says.

“Miguel, did you?” Linh asks.

You pull out your phone, and sure enough, there was a notification from an unsaved number with the same exact message as Linh’s. “Yeah.”

“That’s so weird,” Linh says. “Maybe Massmail just takes longer to send since they’re more detailed and properly formatted?”

“Girl, if there was a murder on my turf, I’d be telling everyone and their moms about it ASAP. Screw formatting. I’d type like Andrew if it means warning everyone faster,” Ricky says.

Linh frowned, knowing he made a point.

“They’ll probably send an email soon,” you say, trying to convince yourself as well.

“Until then, I guess we still got class,” Linh sighs.

The three of you spend the rest of lunch in nervous conversation, glancing at each of your phones every now and then in anticipation for the Massmail.

No email came.

“I’m ‘a head out,” Linh says after checking the time.

“‘Ight, me too,” Ricky says as he begins cleaning up his lunch.

“Be safe,” you three tell each other.

You start clearing the table too, deciding you can continue working on CS at Grainger before calc.

You head back to the main quad after a productive hour at Grainger. You had made decent progress on the project.

You’re about a hop, skip, and jump away from Altgeld Hall when a hard object bashes your cheek. You fall over to the ground and hear screams from around. You can hardly process the smell of blood oozing from your mouth before a second hit strikes from the back of your head. And a third hit. And a fourth hit. The last thing you see is the stained cement beneath you.

You head back to the main quad after a productive hour at Grainger. You had made decent progress on the project.

You meet Linh right before your calc class and tell her about how close you are to finishing the project.

“Ooh, I’m excited to see how it turns out!” she says as the two of you head inside the classroom.

Two hours of discussion and confusion flew by, and Linh waits for you to pack up your things.

“You know what I’m craving right now?” she asks.

“What?” you ask.

“Kimbap.”

You gasp. “I can make some today! I have nothing else to do. Maybe I can text John and Helen to come help.”

“Really?” Linh says excitedly. “I was just gonna buy some from Spoon House, but that’s even better; free food!”
Ask Helen and John to help you make kimbap because kimbap takes work.
Wait... It’s not safe. Maybe you should make kimbap by yourself.

After you send Helen and John a text, you and Linh head out of Altgeld.

“I’m gonna stay at the Union,” Linh says. “I have to do things for my sorority.”

“Oh, okay. I’m gonna go to Bromley and make kimbap.”

Linh suddenly dramatically gasps and points. “Tyler!” she yells.

Tyler, who was heading towards Green Street, turned. He waits as Linh darts towards him, with you following closely behind. They exchange a few words, and you ask if he wants kimbap.

“Sure.”

(You were gonna make some for him regardless of his answer.)

The three of you say your goodbyes, and you head to Bromley. You check your phone for updates. Helen and John responded, saying they were available to help. You then check the group chat: Norb asked if anyone wanted late night, and Helen replied with a maybe, depending on how long it would take to prepare kimbap.

They still haven’t sent a Massmail.

You didn’t realize how stupid it’d be to invite Helen and John with a murderer out and about until they arrived. They didn’t seem to either.

“Yo, there was barely anyone on the bus,” Helen said. “I didn’t realize how dangerous it’d be until the bus was already moving.”

“So are we still making kimbap then?” John asked.

“I guess not,” you reply. “It’s not safe to go grocery shopping.”

The three of you pass the time spilling rumors surrounding the crime, until three phones nearly simultaneously sound.

“They sent an email!” you announce, immediately recognizing the email preview.

The three of you dive for your phones.

“Holy shit!” Helen exclaims. She pushes up her glasses as she begins reading the email. “‘We have been notified that students, faculty and staff have received an Illini Alert that links an article breaking news of a homicide on campus. We can assure you no such crime was committed, and the system overlooking the distribution of Illini Alerts is under investigation.’”

“Bro,” John says.

“That’s crazy,” Helen comments. “Does this mean they got hacked?”

“But who would send out an alert about a murder?” you say.

“Yeah, whoever did it took it too far,” Helen says.

“But this means we can make kimbap!” you realize.

Your phone buzzes in your hand. Linh texted you.

Linh: i just realized making kimbap was a dumb idea bc you wouldn’t be able to give it to anyone if there really was a murderer on the loose

Linh: but now you can :DDD

You: !!!

You: Now I make kimbap

You: Hopefully without getting murdered D:

Linh: okie okie

Linh: nah you gonna die :)))

Linh: i’m in my dorm rn so you can stop by whenever!

You pause. Didn’t she say she was gonna be at the Union for her sorority?

You dismiss the thought. Whatever she was supposed to do must have been canceled.

Your phone buzzes in your hand again. Sue texted the group chat.

Sue: r u guys still making kimbap?

You: Yes!

Sue: did u go get ingredients yet?

You: We’re about to go to Far East Grocery

Sue: oh okok

Sue: just b careful bc campus is hella shady now

You thumbs-up-reacted her message and got ready to head out.

The three of you take your time grocery shopping, and you finalize and pay for the ingredients. You’re following Helen and John out the store when you drop your pickled radish.

Just when you pick it up, an elbow strikes the back of your head, your body dropping alongside the radish you accidentally release again. There’s yelling, but voices blur together and you can’t tell who’s yelling or where it’s coming from.

Something rocky gives another blow. It was so powerful it probably broke in half as soon as it landed on your head, but you can’t even feel the throbbing pain

“I’m gonna stay at the Union,” Linh says after you two exit Altgeld. “I have to do things for my sorority.”

“Oh, okay. I’m gonna go to my brother’s apartment and make kimbap.”

Linh suddenly dramatically gasps and points. “Tyler!” she yells.

Tyler, who was heading towards Green Street, turned. He waits as Linh darts towards him, with you following closely behind. They exchange a few words, and you ask if he wants kimbap.

“Sure.”

(You were gonna make some for him regardless of his answer.)

The three of you say your goodbyes, and you head back to your brother’s apartment. You check your phone for updates. Norb asked if anyone wanted late night, and people were saying yes.

They still haven’t sent a Massmail.

As you reached your brother’s apartment, you realized grocery shopping with a murderer out and about wasn’t a good idea. You instead spend the next few hours crocheting—another hobby you recently picked up, and one that didn’t involve going outside.

An Outlook notification sound goes off, and you glance at your phone. Upon spotting the word “MASSMAIL”, you practically shove the bunny you were crocheting away from you as you scramble to open the email you’ve been awaiting. You scan the text until you got to its core: “We have been notified that students, faculty and staff have received an Illini Alert that links an article breaking news of a homicide on campus. We can assure you no such crime was committed, and the system overlooking the distribution of Illini Alerts is under investigation.”

You wonder who would pull such a prank, but you decide not to worry about it. You realize you can make kimbap—with Helen and John too. You send them a text and set out to Far East Grocery.

Your phone buzzes in your hand. Linh texted you.

Linh: i just realized making kimbap was a dumb idea bc you wouldn’t be able to give it to anyone if there really was a murderer on the loose

Linh: but now you can :DDD

You: !!!

You: Now I make kimbap

You: Hopefully without getting murdered D:

Linh: okie okie

Linh: nah you gonna die :)))

Linh: i’m in my dorm rn so you can stop by whenever!

You pause. Didn’t she say she was gonna be at the Union for her sorority?

You dismiss the thought. Whatever she was supposed to do must have been canceled.

Your phone buzzes in your hand again. Helen and John responded, and you tell them to meet at Bromley when they would be free. Within a few hours, you were able to go shopping and meet up with Helen and John to make a large quantity of kimbap. The three of you are now on your ways to FAR/PAR.

It is 10:00 PM. Helen asks you and John when everyone should meet up at Ricky’s and Tyler’s room, taking into account the people who were eating late night.

Tyler: ok linh and kc are already there

The three of you spend the rest of the bus ride theorizing the alerts and the person behind them.

“It’s most likely a student,” John says.

“I agree,” you say.

A sudden thought came to mind.

“What if,” you start, “the email was actually fake and the alerts were real? And the murderer hacked into the Massmail system to cover up the crime?”

“What kinda Uno reverse card shit?” Helen says.

John laughs, but you start thinking about how brilliant the plan would be. If a student could hack Illini Alerts, who’s to say a person can’t hack Massmail?

The bus drops you off at PAR, and John swipes all of you into Saunders. You arrive at room 231, spotting Ricky’s and Tyler’s cute coffee mug name tags, and Helen unlocks the door. A soft clang immediately follows and you spot KC—a guilty look on her face.

“Uh,” Helen utters.

“Hello,” KC innocently greets.

“Is everything okay?” Helen asks.

“Yes.”

For an actress, her lies were ridiculously obvious.

“Where’s Linh?”

“In the bathroom.”

You enter the room, drop off your bag, and slip off your sneakers. You’re about to settle on the floor when you notice small stains—bright red and fresh. Was that blood? Just beyond the stains was a knife coated in the same substance, lying in what Ricky deemed the Love Shaq, a fort Linh and Ricky built underneath his bed. Maybe someone was trying to cut through strawberry cake.

Yes, you had made that before—for Ricky’s birthday. Which was five months ago. And strawberry purée was viscous compared to the substance covering the knife.

“Miguel,” KC calls from behind you, scaring you out of your thoughts. Was the knife what caused the clang when you had first entered the room? “I need to talk to you. Alone.”

You don’t turn to her. Fear paralyzes you as you think back to your theory. If a student could hack Illini Alerts, who’s to say a person can’t hack Massmail? Who’s to say one of your friends isn’t that person?

“Miguel, I really need to talk to you. Like, now.”

Suddenly, the door opens and before you have a chance to see who entered, something pricks your neck and you’re fast asleep.

Tyler: ok linh and kc are already there

The three of you spend the rest of the bus ride theorizing the alerts and the person behind them.

“It’s most likely a student,” John says.

“I agree,” you say.

A sudden thought came to mind.

“What if,” you start, “the email was actually fake and the alerts were real? And the murderer hacked into the Massmail system to cover up the crime?”

“What kinda Uno reverse card shit?” Helen says.

John laughs, but you start thinking about how brilliant the plan would be. If a student could hack Illini Alerts, who’s to say a person can’t hack Massmail?

The bus drops you off at PAR, and John swipes all of you into Saunders. You arrive at room 231, spotting Ricky’s and Tyler’s cute coffee mug name tags, and Helen unlocks the door. A soft clang immediately follows and you spot KC—a guilty look on her face.

“Uh,” Helen utters.

“Hello,” KC innocently greets.

“Is everything okay?” Helen asks.

“Yes.”

For an actress, her lies were ridiculously obvious.

“Where’s Linh?”

“In the bathroom.”

You enter the room, drop off your bag, and slip off your sneakers. You’re about to settle on the floor when you notice small stains—bright red and fresh. Was that blood? Just beyond the stains was a knife coated in the same substance, lying in what Ricky deemed the Love Shaq, a fort Linh and Ricky built underneath his bed. Maybe someone was trying to cut through strawberry cake.

Yes, you had made that before—for Ricky’s birthday. Which was five months ago. And strawberry purée was viscous compared to the substance covering the knife.

“Miguel,” KC calls from behind you, scaring you out of your thoughts. Was the knife what caused the clang when you had first entered the room? “I need to talk to you. Alone.”

You don’t turn to her. Fear paralyzes you as you think back to your theory. If a student could hack Illini Alerts, who’s to say a person can’t hack Massmail? Who’s to say one of your friends isn’t that person?

“Miguel, I really need to talk to you. Like, now.”

“Uh, I’m gonna go to the bathroom,” you stammer.

“Miguel, this is really important,” she urges, but you’re already heading to the bathroom.

You speed walk to the nearest vacant bathroom and lock yourself in.

You would wait. Yes, you would wait until everyone’s back from late night, when there would be more witnesses. You check your Fitbit—about 10 more minutes until everyone should be back.

“Miguel.” KC was knocking on his door. Maybe you should have thought further than fleeing to the bathroom.

She suddenly stopped knocking when the toilet next door flush. Was that Linh? Whoever it was, the person drove KC away, and you were thankful to be left alone.

Several minutes pass when the lights turn off. You yelp in surprise, but realize that the motion detectors weren’t detecting any movement, so you begin pacing back and forth.

When you’re almost sure it’s time the rest of the group returned, you press your ear against the door, making sure you wouldn’t walk right into an ambush. You open the door and peek out; the hallway was empty.

You walk back to Ricky’s and Tyler’s room and decide you can tell them you weren’t feeling well  and leave.

You enter the room and pick up your belongings, muttering, “I’m gonna leave.”

“But you just got here,” Tyler says.

You mumble your excuse and bend down to tie your shoes when something pokes—no, injects—your side. You turn and lock eyes with your hitman before you collapse.

“Uh, okay,” you say.

KC leads you to the lounge, making sure it was vacant. “Someone’s trying to kill you.”

Your heart dropped. “What?”

“I found this note, but I don’t know whose it is.” KC hands you a scrunched up piece of paper.

The note reads, “Kill Miguel F. by all means necessary. You know what happens when you don’t. I’ll handle administration.”

Just when you thought your heart couldn’t sink any more than it already has, you felt it drop to your stomach, which was churning in apprehension and fear.

“I found it tucked underneath the refrigerator, and there was also a knife covered in...”

Was this real?

“Was anyone else in the room before you?” you ask.

“No, just Ricky and Tyler.”

A door handle audibly turned, and the two of you instinctively faced in its direction. Linh had just finished using the bathroom.

“We should go back,” KC says in a low voice.

“Yeah,” you agree.

You didn’t realize what a horrible decision it was until everyone came back. If someone in the group really was trying to kill you, that means if everyone is present, there’s a hundred percent chance the murderer is there.

While everyone jokes and banters, you sit in silence, observing everyone. The only one who is off is KC, who throws nervous glances at you, every now and then, but that’s because she knows.

“Miguel, are you okay?” Ricky asks.

“Someone here is trying to kill me,” you blurt.

Half the room goes silent, the other half goes, “What?”

“It’s KC!”

“Um, what?” she says.

Everyone in the room stares at KC, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to her. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to.

“It’s Linh!”

“Um, what?” she says.

Everyone in the room stares at Linh, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to her. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to.

“It’s Tyler!”

“Um, what?” he says.

Everyone in the room stares at Tyler, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to him. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to..

“It’s Sue!”

“What?” she says.

Everyone in the room stares at Sue, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to her. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to.

“It’s Norb!”

“Uh, what?” he says.

Everyone in the room stares at Norb, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to him. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to.

“It’s John!”

“Um, what?” he says.

Everyone in the room stares at John, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to him. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to.

“It’s Helen!”

“Uh, what?” she says.

Everyone in the room stares at Helen, but you made the wrong decision in diverting everyone’s attention—including your own—to her. Something injects into your arm, and you’ve never knocked out so fast in your life.

Nor would you have any more chances to.

“It’s Ricky!”

Ricky instantly jumps up and pulls out a syringe needle about to pounce, when the rest of the group reacts and holds him down.

“LET ME GO. I NEED HIM DEAD.”

Seven against one, Ricky is unable to land an attack on you. You stare at him, shocked and speechless, while everyone else was fiercely yelling.

The door to the dorm bursts open, and in the doorway was a young man you don’t recognize. Was he the RA?

“What’s going—holy shit.”

Ricky grows more rabid, and even seven people struggle with keeping him in place. The stranger notices the syringe, walks in the room, and seizes it. He did it so effortlessly he almost stunned the room into silence.

“What is this? A tranquilizer?”

Suddenly, Ricky leaps onto the stranger, knocking him over to the floor. It quickly dawns on the stranger that Ricky’s intent was murderous. Panicking, the stranger injects the needle into Ricky’s neck, immediately slowing his movements until he completely stops.

You thought you have never been more afraid when he was ready to stab you with that exact needle, but witnessing Ricky’s death was something that haunted your mind and permanently scarred your soul.

Game and Story by Miguel Fernandez and Linh Pham

Miguel played by Miguel Fernandez

Linh played by Linh Pham

Ricky played by Ricardo Ramirez

Helen played by Helen Huynh

John played by John Tang

KC played by KC Rivera

Norb played by Norberto Nieves

Tyler played by Tyler Tang

Sue played by Sue Wee
